name: Improve Your Research Workflow Using Text Network Visualization
desc: You can visualize all the research notes and quotes you have in a graph, so you can see how it all connects, what are the main topics inside, how they relate to each other ....

name: How to use Zotero in your Research Workflow
desc: This video takes you through the three stage research workflow of Collecting, Organize and Citing your research using the free apps from Zotero.

name: Reproducible Data Analysis in Jupyter
desc: Jupyter notebooks provide a useful environment for interactive exploration of data. This series of videos presents a case study in how to approach reproducible data analysis within the Jupyter notebook.

name: Searching Google Scholar
desc: University students need to ensure that they are relying on credible, academic sources for their research. In recent years, Google has created its own academic database that may be more familiar to students used to using this search engine. When used correctly, Google Scholar can be a great research tool. To avoid information overload, however, watch this tutorial and follow the tips provided.

name: Creative User Research Methods for Startups
desc: The UX Research tool kit expands beyond traditional methods like usability tests and focus groups; come hear about creative UX research methods that can get insight in unexpected, quick ways to inform product decisions.

name: Research Culture is Broken; Open Science can Fix It
desc: After the increasingly toxic environment of modern research culture forced her to nearly abandon her career, astrophysicist Dr Rachael Ainsworth began to question why the subject she loved had become so inhospitable. Identifying some of the pressures placed on her peers that encouraged aggressive competitiveness, unfair benchmarking and shoddy research practices also helped her identify a compelling potential solution.

name: The Turing Way: A how to guide for reproducible research
desc: Kirstie Whitaker will present The Turing Way: a lightly opinionated guide to reproducible data science. Openly developed and community-led, this online book curates resources, case studies and checklists to make reproducible research 'Too easy not to do'.

name: Lean vs Agile vs Design Thinking
desc: As companies evolve to adopt, integrate, and leverage software as the defining element of their success in the 21st century, a rash of processes and methodologies are vying for their product teams' attention. In the worst of cases, each discipline on these teams -- product management, design, and software engineering -- learns a different model. This short, tactical talk reconciles the perceived differences in Lean Startup, Design Thinking, and Agile software development by focusing not on rituals and practices but on the values that underpin all three methods.

name: Beyond Design Thinking
desc: Design thinking seems to have taken the world by storm as hundreds of companies puzzle over how to integrate it into their organizations. Some claim outstanding results, others less so. In this session, we will dig under the hype, identify the core elements of what design thinking represents, and examine the path design thinking might take to be meaningful and useful in the future.

name: Getting started in R and RStudio
desc: Tutorial on the relationship between R and RStudio and how to install both pieces of software. Produced for use in my own teaching. Best viewed as part of the interactive tutorial at http://milton-the-cat.rocks/learnr/r/...

name: HR @Tableau | Improving our commute with employee survey data
desc: Transportation benefits are one way for companies to differentiate themselves in recruiting great talent. Using our own HR survey data, we were able to derive valuable insights into employee commute behavior and design a more effective transportation program.

name: How to Use Cornell Notes
desc: Learn how students use the Cornell Note Taking System.

name: Establish The Terms of Engagement During First Client Meeting
desc: What questions should I ask during the first client meeting? How you respond, during the first critical meeting with a design client, will determine if you will be in a position of power, or struggling to regain authority. Chris & Jose give you a step-by-step on how to handle your first meeting with a client.

name: Systematic Reviews: An Introduction
desc: This introduction to systematic reviews includes an explanation of what systematic reviews are, their history, the process involved in completing a systematic review, and an overview of how they differ from other common types of reviews. The video is not meant to be an in-depth examination of systematic reviews, but an overview to familiarize yourself with the publication type.

name: Get started with Google Colaboratory
desc: Want to get started with Google Colaboratory? In this episode of Coding TensorFlow, Software Engineer, Jake VanderPlas breaks down exactly what you need to get started with Colab. Colaboratory is a free Jupyter notebook environment that requires no setup, and runs entirely (writing, running, & sharing code) on the Cloud. Watch to learn more, and subscribe to get notified for the next Colab series episode, that focuses on the use of TensorFlow in Colab!

name: Improving Cornell Notes With Sketchnoting Techniques
desc: Make Cornell notes a bit more effective and a bit more visual by adding in some sketchnoting techniques.

name: Comparing EndNote, Mendeley, and Zotero
desc: Choosing citation management software and something to organize research materials requires a bit of thought. This video will provide brief overviews of the strengths and weaknesses of three popular options: EndNote, Mendeley, and Zotero.

name: Top 10 Logical Fallacies
desc: When creating a logical argument, there are many different aspects that have to come together to ensure that your argument is sound and does not contain any flaws. One of these aspects is avoiding what we call “logical fallacies.” A logical fallacy is an error of reasoning that will weaken your argument and, in most cases, undermine it completely.

name: Gitbook: Great Free-ish Tool to Build Your Docs Page
desc: Build a good-looking and searchable documentation for your projects, or private docs for your dev team.

name: Online Survey Methodology Guidelines
desc: Practical advise for conducting survey research online. Topics include: Solicitation strategies, design issues unique to psychology, and a comparison of platforms (e.g., SurveyMonkey vs. psychsurveys.org).

name: Jamovi for Data Analysis
desc: Open-source application that makes data analysis easy and intuitive.

name: How to Use JASP for Statistics
desc: Learn how to use Jasp for statistical analysis. This video will show you how JASP works, demonstrate its similarity with other statistics software, and get you familiar with how “progressive disclosure” allows you to focus on the analysis as you work

name: Event Storming
desc: Event Storming Event Storming is a highly visual, collaborative domain discovery and modelling method. It's a great way to get started sharing domain knowledge with different stakeholders.

name: The Rise Of Open-Source Software
desc: Open-source software powers nearly all the world’s major companies. This software is freely available, and is developed collaboratively, maintained by a broad network that includes everyone from unpaid volunteers to employees at competing tech companies. Here’s how giving away software for free has proven to be a viable business model.

name: Comparative Cognitive Mapping
desc: This video is part of our online course Multi-stakeholder Strategies: Analysis for Winning Coalitions.

name: How to ask a question: conducting research for your startup
desc: Join Google Search User Experience researcher Tomer Sharon as he shares interview techniques to help you get better answers in your customer research.

name: Learn to build your personal brand
desc: Donna Rachelson is founder of Branding & Marketing YOU a business focused on helping people develop and grow their personal brands

name: Build Your Brand on LinkedIn
desc: Learn why a strong personal brand is important for successful recruiting efforts, define the key components of a compelling personal profile, and learn ways to enhance your personal brand beyond your profile.

name: Correlation vs Causation: A Brief Guide To Communicating Research
desc: Using causal language when reporting research that only provides evidence of a correlation is one of the most common errors in science reporting.

name: Video is the Core Communication Tool of the Future
desc: Capturing and sharing video is now easier than ever. Yet consuming and creating with video remains hard. Our video interfaces today are still rooted in a timeline and force users to deal with individual frames despite advances in video understanding that now show who is in a video, what they are saying, and how they feel. In this talk Mira will present a framework for understanding common video tasks followed by research projects that point to possibilities for future video interaction.

name: How to use OBS for Screen Recording or Streaming
desc: In this step-by-step tutorial, learn how to get started using Open Broadcaster Software. OBS is an extremely powerful and versatile screen recorder and allows you to stream to services like Twitch, Facebook, and YouTube.

name: Project Retrospective
desc: Tom Wijmenga van Aresz Project Professionals legt in deze video uit hoe je een goede project retrospective met je team organiseert zodat ook jou project de volgende keer nóg beter gaat.

name: Quantum Computing Expert Explains One Concept in 5 Levels of Difficulty
desc: WIRED has challenged IBM's Dr. Talia Gershon (Senior Manager, Quantum Research) to explain quantum computing to 5 different people; a child, teen, a college student, a grad student and a professional

name: Meet Coda
desc: Coda is a new doc that brings words, data, and teams together. It starts with a blinking cursor on a blank page and can grow as big as your team's ambition. Coda comes with a set of building blocksーlike pages for infinite depth, tables that talk to each other, and buttons that take action inside or outside your docーwhich anyone can combine to make a doc as powerful as an app. People have made Coda docs that do everything from launch products, to scale small businesses, to help them study for tests. What will you Coda?

name: The dschool Starter Kit
desc: The d.school Starter Kit is an online intro to design where you'll learn a medley of design abilities, methods, & mindsets.

name: Epics, User Stories & Tasks
desc: This video goes into more detail on the process of documenting requirements for the Product Backlog via the concept of Epics and User Stories and follows the Agile SCRUM methodology.

name: Making the web more visual with Web Stories
desc: Web Stories are a web-based version of the popular Stories format that blend video, audio, images, animation, and text to create a dynamic consumption experience. Learn about the why, what, and how of Web Stories and how Google has gone the extra mile to let Web Stories shine by providing the right tools and the right guidance for content creators to succeed on the web.

name: How Open Source Changed My Life with Max Stoiber
desc: Despite his young age of only 23, Max has achieved incredible things: he's created react-boilerplate and styled-components, his start-up, Spectrum, was recently acquired by GitHub and he gives talks all over the world. Learn more about his journey - and how he dropped out of university (twice!) - in this mini-doc.

name: Essential Tips for Collecting Great User Feedback
desc: Is user research worth it?🤔 Is it actually something you should do? How the #$%@ should you capture the data? If you want to improve your product, you MUST interview your users, or potential users. How should you document the feedback from the users? What tool should you use? No sweat. We’ve got you covered!🎯In our latest video, we dive into the ULTIMATE way to capture feedback from users!

name: Zero to UX: Escape the Research Death Spiral
desc: In order to create great products, proper UX research methods should be applied. Watch this video to learn how to avoid the most common UX research pitfalls.

name: Open Knowledge Maps
desc: In this webinar, founder Peter Kraker introduces Open Knowledge Maps, an interface that searches databases for research and presents search results visually, in the form of knowledge maps. The knowledge maps provide an instant overview of a topic by showing the main areas researched at a glance, and papers related to each area. Papers found are clustered together into similar topics.

name: Network Analysis with Gephi
desc: In this video, I show you how to install and use Gephi to do some basic network analysis of a large Ming dynasty social network derived from the China Biographical Database

name: What is A/B Testing?
desc: In this quick tutorial, we go over the basics of A/B testing, as well as answer some in-depth questions such as: why should businesses conduct A/B testing? Or how do you perform an A/B test?

name: Research impact: The impact cycle of research projects
desc: The research impact cycle: ever wondered how research impact evolves and how you can plan it? Then watch this vlog on the impact cycle tool. Have fun!

name: Watch me build a web app in 10 minutes without using code
desc: In this video I am building a searchable NoCode tools directory on bubble.io. I time myself to see if I can do it in under 10 minutes.

name: How I Organise My Life with Roam
desc: In this video, I'll be taking you through how I use Roam on a daily basis to take smart notes and organise all things important to me.

name: Roam Research - My Daily Review Workflow
desc: This is my current, and subject to change, daily review workflow using Roam Research.

name: Introduction to experiment design
desc: Introduction to experiment design. Explanatory and response variables. Control and treatment groups.

name: Jonge wetenschappers willen de wereld verbeteren
desc: Maud Hartstra en Juliette Boughouf van Thrive spreken jonge wetenschappers over kwantumfysica, circulair design en gedragseconomie!

name: RPA and Process Mining
desc: Process Mining lets you understand your process data and their dependencies to find patterns, anomalies and opportunities for improvement. Compare designed processes to as-is processes to see if they execute as planned and make changes before they impact your bottom line. Simulate and analyze process optimization scenarios to determine the best path to improvement. RPA, standing for robotic process automation, except with AI and machine learning included – has long been the future as a form of business process automation technology, harnessing software robots or AI (artificial intelligence) units or digital workers.

name: Analysing Textual Data
desc: * Content analysis: conceptual analysis and relational analysis * Coding scheme development: inductive, deductive, hybrid, coding scheme structure * Coding in Atlas.ti: open coding, applying codes, coding to facilitate relational analysis * Analysis and output in Atlas.ti: conceptual analysis, and relational analysis

name: Making Data-driven Decisions in Business
desc: Learn about how data can empower our decisions, big and small, the difference between quantitative and qualitative analysis and when to use them, the pros and cons of different data visualization tools, what metrics are and how analysts use them, and how to use mathematical thinking to connect the dots.

name: Agent-Based Modeling
desc: These videos are from the Introduction to Agent Based Modeling course on Complexity Explorer (complexityexplorer.org) taught by Prof. Bill Rand. This course will explore how to use agent-based modeling to understand and examine a widely diverse and disparate set of complex problems.

name: How to level up your business's digital transformation
desc: How we use process mining as the starting point to support your digital transformation.

name: Communication Do's and Don't for Data Analysts
desc: It’s important to keep your team members’ and stakeholders’ needs in mind. You can use these communication best practices in your day-to-day work. Remember, communication is key. Think of these skills as new tools that’ll help you work with your team to find the best possible solutions.

name: FlowChartsAI - Create Smart Flow Charts, Questionnaires, Forms, Workflows & Dynamic Surveys
desc: https://FlowCharts.AI​ lets you both create and administer smart flow charts, workflows, decision trees, dynamic surveys and questionnaire forms. We have developed a smart dynamic and interactive survey engine in which you can add your own questions and have your respondent be magically routed through your flowchart & workflow depending on their answers to your questions. You can choose different responses, yes/no, free text, single choice and multiple-choice to your questions. You can also steer your survey according to conditions, i.e. you can ask follow-up questions depending on how the respondent answers a particular question, all logic-driven.

name: Notion Training: The Basics
desc: Welcome to Notion! This video will cover the basics: * Add & edit content * Set up your workspace * Collaborate with teammates

name: How To Give Feedback To Teams That Empower & Engage Creativity
desc: How to manage and lead creative teams in a way that doesn't make you a micromanager and stifle the creativity of others? How do you multiply your team by giving feedback? What is the proper way to give feedback? How do you give good direction without robbing your team's creativity?

name: Root Cause Analysis Techniques With Examples
desc: This video on Root Cause Analysis Techniques explains different root cause analysis techniques with examples and how these techniques help in effective problem-solving in quality management.

name: Root Cause Analysis Tools
desc: Root Cause Analysis gets better results with the right tools. Try some of these ideas and see if they help make your process more effective!

name: Spice up Your UX Research - Creativity Methods
desc: Often we get stuck using the same research methods over and over again, and that is all well and good, but when you use different methods you can find different quality of results. The method you choose dictates the data that you get!

name: How to Write a Research Methodology in 4 Steps
desc: Learn how to write a strong methodology chapter that allows readers to evaluate the reliability and validity of the research. A good methodology chapter includes the type of research you did, how you collected and analyzed your data, any tools or materials you used in the research, and your rationale for choosing these methods.

name: Critical Reading & Writing Technique From Harvard University
desc: Since 2018, I have been developing a research thesis report writing course. I've taken all the feedback and questions from my videos over the last few years and complied the ULTIMATE guide for writing your thesis. Everything from creating a blank thesis template on Word, devising the research question, searching for papers and writing each chapter is included. For each chapter, I have provided a list of words and phrases that can be used as sentence starters, to guide you smoothly through the writing process. I know how daunting it can be, especially seeing that blank page and with no clue how to begin.

name: Explaining your research in one minute
desc: How do you explain science and scientific research to people with a non-scientific background? Anders Sahlman, science communicator and presentation coach gives you his best advice.

name: Case Study Research
desc: Case study research is an investigation and analysis of a single or collective case, intended to capture the complexity of the object of study. A case study is a detailed study of a specific subject, such as a person, group, place, event, organization, or phenomenon. Case studies are commonly used in social, architectural, educational, clinical, and business research.

name: Digital Diaries as Social Research Method
desc: This short webinar is presented by Dr Marianne Clark, from the Vitalities Lab at UNSW Sydney. It explains the theory and approach she used in a project involving asking participants to make digital diaries.

name: The Story Completion Method
desc: A brief webinar introduction by Professor Deborah Lupton from the University of New South Wales (UNSW) Sydney on to how to do the story completion method for social research

name: TikTok Methods
desc: A short webinar by Dr Clare Southerton, UNSW Sydney, on methods for analysing TikTok videos

name: Map Making as a Social Research Method
desc: This short webinar presented by Professor Deborah Lupton from the University of New South Wales (UNSW) Sydney provides details on how to use hand-drawn maps as a method for social research

name: Identifying Graph Shaped Problems
desc: Graph databases are an excellent choice for storing and querying your connected data. They allow you to store information in a logical and complementary way that’s reflective of the domain you’re working in. However, when faced with the questions you’re looking to answer, it may not be immediately obvious that what you’re looking at is a graph question.

name: Learning How to Learn
desc: Dr. Oakley lets us in on the secrets to effectively learning math and science—secrets that even dedicated and successful students wish they’d known earlier. Contrary to popular belief, math requires creative, as well as analytical, thinking. Most people think that there’s only one way to do a problem, when in actuality, there are often a number of different solutions—you just need the creativity to see them.

name: How to Use the Obsidian App for Notes
desc: This is the ultimate Obsidian HOW TO. Learn how to supercharge your note-taking and note-making. Learn the power of the Obsidian App in this practical course from Linking Your Thinking. In this video, you'll learn exactly the simple steps on how to get started .

name: Great User Research for Non Researchers
desc: The importance of including users in the product development process has never been more accepted than it is now. Yet the specific skills and processes required to do this crucial work well remain elusive still. In this talk, Steve explains the essentials of planning, conducting, and acting on user research, showing you how to uncover insightful information to help drive UX and product decisions.

name: What are Metadata (and why are they so important)?
desc: This video tells you some of the many reasons why metadata are important.

name: Essential Google search tricks for academic research
desc: Essential Google search tricks for academic research (that most people don't know!)

name: Creativity: Agile Tools & Processes
desc: You are more creative than you think! Are you ready for an afternoon date with your creative self? At Growth Vikings we want to introduce you to a personal agile creativity toolkit designed for curious hearts like your!

name: Remote Retrospective
desc: 54 retrospectives in the last 5 months allowed me to come up with a framework and tools that can help you create engaging and unforgettable remote retrospectives! Enjoy!

name: Deep Dive into Open Scholarship: Collaboration and Replication
desc: This deep dive session on replications and large-scale collaborations introduces a glossary of relevant terms, the problems these initiatives address, and some tools to get started. Panelists start with content knowledge transfer but switch to more interactive conversation for Q&A and conversation.

name: OSF101
desc: OSF is a free, open source web application built by the Center for Open Science, a non-profit dedicated to improving the alignment between scientific values and scientific practices. OSF is part collaboration tool, part version control software, and part data archive. It is designed to connect to popular tools researchers already use, like Dropbox, Box, Github, and Mendeley, to streamline workflows and increase efficiency.

name: Why we need the Open Science Framework
desc: Introduction to OSF.

name: Leveraging Open Ecosystems to Enhance Reproducible Workflows
desc: Hear from a panel of research groups that have taken advantage of interoperable infrastructure to leverage more robust workflows to support rigorous, reproducible research. We also discuss the steps stakeholders and institutions can take to integrate OSF’s open API with existing services to establish streamlined researcher workflows.

name: Airtable Demo
desc: This video presents an overview of a popular project management solution, Airtable.

name: An introduction to processing personal data for research purposes
desc: This webinar will cover data life-cycle management and what to consider before data collection, storage, sharing and archiving. The aim is to enable researchers and others working with personal data to make the most out of collected data, whilst also meeting requirements in data protection legislation and respecting the rights of data subjects.

name: Make great video presentations with mmhmm
desc: Mmhmm helps you perform, present, and entertain on video. Works with Zoom, Google Meet, and many other video products. Try it for yourself at mmhmm.app.

name: Design Science Research
desc: This is a short summary of the main points of Lecture 8 of the Research Methodology and Thesis Design course 2020/2021.

name: YouTube as Qualitative Data
desc: In this short webinar, Dr Clare Southerton, Vitalities Lab, UNSW Sydney, describes how to analyse Youtube videos using qualitative research methods.

name: The General Linear Model
desc: This lecture is the first of a series describing the General Linear Model as SPINE of statistics. This lecture looks at what the linear model is, and how parameters are estimated.

name: Charticulator Visual IS HERE
desc: We walk through a first look at the new Charticulator visual from Microsoft Power BI team.

name: Understanding Decision-Driven Analytics
desc: Bart De Langhe, a behavioral scientist and marketing professor at ESADE, Ramon Llull University, and Stefano Puntoni, a professor of marketing at the Rotterdam School of Management at Erasmus University and the director of the Psychology of AI lab at the Erasmus Centre for Data Analytics, explain how organizations can make better decisions with data.

name: Experiment your way through change
desc: Research shows that leaders who fail to involve and engage people in change cause increased uncertainty and fear. But how can leaders stop their people from feeling that things are “happening to them,” and instead feel they are a vital and valuable part of the change? Simple. Experiment your way through change!

name: Intro to FlutterFlow
desc: A brief overview of how FlutterFlow works, and how you can use it to help build your application!

name: This tool will help improve your critical thinking
desc: Explore the technique known as the Socratic Method, which uses questions to examine a person’s values, principles, and beliefs.

name: The Case for More Silent Meetings
desc: Talking meetings have much merit, but can also be subject to a host of problems. The good news is that alternative approaches do exist and, depending on your task at hand, can work incredibly well. One such approach embraces silence. This technique may seem odd, but current research supports the benefits of holding a “silent meeting” as one way of better leveraging the ideas, perspectives, and insights of organizational talent.

name: How to Analyze Research Data
desc: In this webinar, Associate Professor Kristin Sainani walks you through the steps of a complete data analysis, using real data on mental health in athletes. She provides practical, hands-on tips for how to approach each step of the analysis and how to improve rigor and reproducibility of your research.

name: Story Telling In Business
desc: Sharing personal and professional moments of where you've had success or people who have used your product or use your company have had a positive experience. When you share that, you impact people, you make it memorable and you make it personal.

name: What’s the Point of LinkedIn, Anyway?
desc: It’s the least fun social platform, but the most important for your career. Here’s how to make LinkedIn work for you.

name: Analysing, interpreting and presenting data
desc: This video highlights 5 top tips to help you engage effectively with data. it works through a sample task to suggest how you might analyse, interpret and present data.

name: How to Analyze Qualitative Data
desc: This video shows how to analyze qualitative data with a quick introduction tutorial. Qualitative analysis is an important technique in psychology and many social sciences, although also used in business, architecture, software development and many more.

name: Problem Solving with Data Analytics
desc: Let's talk about how to ask questions that lead to insights that can help you solve business problems. There are six basic problem types to craft effective questions that will help you collect the right data. This video is part of the Google Data Analytics Certificate which teaches learners how to prepare, process, analyze, share, and act on data.

name: You Need Tough Feedback—Here’s How to Get It
desc: In this episode, Innovation Editor Christine Liu sets out to learn how to ask for and get quality feedback, how to react to feedback (good or bad), and how to grow from it. She turns to Octavia Goredema, career coach and founder of Twenty Ten Agency, for answers on how to manage professional feedback.

name: Rapid Prototyping: Sketching
desc: Mariam Shaikh and Melissa Powel talk about sketching and paper prototyping. Have you ever struggled with how to get from an idea to a high fidelity prototype? Every design has to start somewhere and even at Google we often start with low fidelity prototyping options such as sketching and paper prototyping. After all, the fidelity of your prototype should match the fidelity of your idea, so stop worrying and start sketching.

name: The ultimate guide to prototyping
desc: Learn how to design web and mobile app prototypes, how to test them and what to look for in a prototyping tool in this complete guide.

name: Quick Prototyping Workshop X Miro Startup Program
desc: To learn how to build a user’s journey diagram, map assumptions, identify the prototype's requirements, define what to prototype, and ways to do so effectively. Prototyping can save precious resources, reveal assumptions, and biases you have about your ideas, uncover new insights about your users and inspire your stakeholders.

name: Intro to UX Writing | Workshop
desc: This Workshop shows you how to write clear, compelling user-facing content – because better writing leads to better experiences. Create your own content matrix while learning best practices for common UI patterns such as onboarding, notifications, labels, errors, and localization. Lessons focus on English writing, and can be applied across many contexts. Advanced topics such as testing content, conversation design, and machine learning feature writing are covered briefly.

name: The Beautiful Science of Data Visualization
desc: Explore the scientific underpinnings of what enables people to understand data quickly and effectively. In this latest Data Science Central webinar, take a deep dive into how the neuroscience of the human visual system works and learn methods for effectively telling compelling data stories.

name: Short Metabase Demo
desc: A quick demo of the main features of the open source Metabase data analytics platform.

name: UX writing: Designing better product experiences
desc: Storytelling, content strategy, writing-focused design. These labels have been used to help define UX writing. But what, exactly, is it? And why should you care? Find out how words can make or break your product experience. Through case studies on Google products, learn about the UX writing principles that guide effective design decisions across a wide range of product areas, including artificial intelligence & conversation design, social media, messaging, e-commerce, virtual/augmented reality, and education.

name: Principal Component Analysis (PCA), Step-by-Step
desc: Principal Component Analysis, is one of the most useful data analysis and machine learning methods out there. It can be used to identify patterns in highly complex datasets and it can tell you what variables in your data are the most important. Lastly, it can tell you how accurate your new understanding of the data actually is.

name: Kickstart Your Research Process
desc: This playlist will provide you clear steps of the research process, covering broad concepts from explaining different types of research, to pinpointing how to write topic sentences.

name: What is Futures Thinking?
desc: Futures thinking means thinking about how the past and present influence the future. To live more sustainably, we must appreciate the process by which the solutions of the past have become the problems of today. We must anticipate how the solutions of today might become the problems of tomorrow. We need to imagine the potential consequences, both positive and negative, of human activity, and manage that activity to progress toward a more sustainable future.

name: What is Digital Storytelling?
desc: Creating a digital story is an engaging way to share information that requires creativity, self-direction, and experimentation with new technologies.

name: 3 Best Open Source Workflow Management Software & Free BPM Tools
desc: Workflow Management Software is important for keeping businesses organized and efficient, but proprietary tools can get expensive.  Consider some of these open source tools for your business.

name: Ontwikkel je personal brand
desc: Tijdens deze sessie leer je hoe het HHH-model van Google je kan helpen om jezelf online professioneel te profileren. Je krijgt een goed beeld van de verschillende soorten professionele profilering, en ontdekt waar voor jou kansen en opportuniteiten liggen.

name: Creative data collection tools
desc: A run through of various different creative data collection tools as well as Emma and Sam from SELFA, a children's charity in Skipton, presenting how they collect data to monitor, evaluate and present the organisation's activities.

name: Designing the Conceptual Framework
desc: In research writing, the conceptual framework gives readers a glimpse of what the research is aiming to achieve; a well designed conceptual framework includes the variables in the study, as well as a depiction of their relationships and connections in accordance to the research.

name: Social Media Research with Digital Methods
desc: In this Video, Richard Rogers talks about several techniques to study social media platforms. These techniques, broadly known as digital methods, are tool based but also research question-based. This video gives insight into the kinds of research questions typically posed in digital methods, techniques used, outcomes, and how productive these methods can be.

name: How To Choose A Research Topic
desc: Learn how to choose a dissertation topic for your dissertation or thesis using the tried and trusted 7-step method by Grad Coach. In this video, we explain exactly how to find high-quality research topics, how to evaluate potential research topics and how to choose a winner.

name: Reproducible Social Research
desc: The focus of this video is social science research that employs statistical techniques to analyse observational data (e.g. social surveys). Many of the issues associated with undertaking transparent and reproducible data analysis pervade other forms of social science research (e.g. qualitative data analysis), despite the different nature of the data and the analytical techniques that are used.

name: Zotero workshop
desc: Zotero workshop led by James R. Jacobs, Stanford Libraries US Government Information Librarian

name: Conducting UX Research and Testing Prototypes
desc: Learn how to conduct research with a usability study to test your prototype. Once you have your research findings, use the insights to iterate on and improve your prototype, as well as share and promote your research insights.

name: Decision Making at Scale With Wicked Problem Solving
desc: The problem with navigating a crisis is that most of us don’t face them often, so when one starts, we don’t know how to begin tackling it. In this session Tom Wujec walks attendees through the crisis curve; a template to help teams tackle any crisis. By following his template, attendees will be able to stabilize and fix a crisis, and ultimately move beyond it stronger than ever before.

name: Running Interactive Workshops and Meetings
desc: We’ve all experienced “Zoom fatigue,” or the phenomenon of getting burned out by too many virtual meetings. The solution is interactivity, and Miro gives a plethora of options for baking interactivity into meetings and workshops. In this session, Miro’s Matt Mulholland and Lindsey Meredith share easy strategies for driving team engagement by turning any meeting into an interactive workshop using the tools and templates available to all Miro users.

name: Intro to Spreadsheets, Databases, and Query Languages
desc: How do data analysts bring data to life? Well, it starts with the right data analysis tools. These include spreadsheets, databases, query languages, and visualization software. Don’t worry if you are new to these tools, we'll cover them in this video. At one point, every data analyst has been right where you are right now, and they probably had a lot of the same questions.

name: Computer Scientist Explains Machine Learning in 5 Levels of Difficulty
desc: WIRED has challenged computer scientist and Hidden Door cofounder and CEO Hilary Mason to explain machine learning to 5 different people; a child, teen, a college student, a grad student and an expert.

name: The Recipe for Powerful Data Visualization
desc: Learn how to visualize and present your data findings as you complete the data analysis process. This video will show you how data visualizations, such as visual dashboards, can help bring your data to life.

name: R Markdown with RStudio for Beginners
desc: R Markdown is a file format for making dynamic documents with R. Learn to use a R Markdown file as a code notebook to save, organize, and report your analysis to stakeholders.
